intro.speaker: Saizo
intro.line: Hey, Azama, you look terrible. Like you've seen a ghost.

intro.speaker: Azama
intro.line: No, nothing that awful. It's just that my daughter's village is under attack.

intro.speaker: Saizo
intro.line: What? That's FAR worse. We have to get there and rescue her.

intro.speaker: Azama
intro.line: Let's see... I guess it is worse, though everyone has to die sometime.

intro.speaker: Saizo
intro.line: What?! We're talking about your daughter here! Let's get to saving her, man!

intro.speaker: Azama
intro.line: Impatient, aren't you? Then let's go, if you're in such a hurry.

intro.speaker: Saizo
intro.line: My god! The village in this Deeprealm is completely overrun with our enemies! This is where Mitama lives, right? Then where IS your daughter?

intro.speaker: Azama
intro.line: This is not good... I don't see her anywhere... Oh! Ah! I'm wrong. There's an air of calm here. She must be fine.

intro.speaker: Saizo
intro.line: Hmm. Somehow I seriously doubt that. Look at this place, you fool.

intro.speaker: Azama
intro.line: Um, well...she's probably fine. I put her in a perfectly sound house.

intro.speaker: Azama
intro.line: See? That place is still standing. It hasn't taken any damage.

intro.speaker: Saizo
intro.line: ... We're going in to check on her safety, you damned fool.

visit.speaker: Azama
visit.line: Mitama? Knock knock! It's your father. Are you home?

visit.speaker: Mitama
visit.line: Wh-who?

visit.speaker: Azama
visit.line: Oh, you are home. Could you come to the door, please? It's only fair that you join us outside. Or let us all in. Either way.

visit.speaker: Mitama
visit.line: Who? What now? Off with you. I'm enjoying a lovely snooze...

visit.speaker: Azama
visit.line: Oh, my! Did she fall back asleep?

visit.speaker: Azama
visit.line: Mitama? Please open up. My knuckles are getting sore from knocking.

visit.speaker: Mitama
visit.line: Who's there? Didn't I say to go away? I don't want any! Haven't you a higher calling than to trouble my door? Mayhaps you should place yourself in a prostrate position, then perish?

visit.speaker: Azama
visit.line: How strange. Explain yourself, Mitama.

visit.speaker: Mitama
visit.line: How can I make it any clearer? Lay down and die!

visit.speaker: Azama
visit.line: Ah! That most certainly is you, Daughter. I'd know that sharp tongue anywhere. It's your father, Mitama. Open up, pretty please. I'm getting rude stares. People don't understand why you won't let me in. Me? I could stand here all day and banter with you. Great fun. Still, I'd rather not knock a third time. Mitama...?

visit.speaker: Mitama
visit.line: Oh, is that you, Father? What brings you here? Did you bring all these hooligans who've been making so much noise?

visit.speaker: Azama
visit.line: Blissfully unaware, as always. Nice to see you too, Daughter.

visit.speaker: Mitama
visit.line: Yes, well, I've been asleep. Or trying to. But all this noise out here!

visit.speaker: Azama
visit.line: Oh my. What a dreamer! You might have slept through your house being razed. Good thing I had the common sense to get here as fast I could.

visit.speaker: Mitama
visit.line: I understand. You're saving me. That's worth waking up for. Or at least it's haiku worthy. My father has come. / But my feather bed is warm. / So I choose to snooze. Good night, Father.

visit.speaker: Azama
visit.line: Good night, my left foot! Have you taken a look around? It's not night! And it's not good - not with your village being under attack! Outside, now. If I have to battle, you have to battle.

visit.speaker: Mitama
visit.line: What? Why?

visit.speaker: Azama
visit.line: Dear Daughter, do I really need to explain? You're brighter than most. It's time that your laziness is forged into the will to fight. Besides, I need you to heal me up if I scuff my knee.

visit.speaker: Mitama
visit.line: You woke me for this? I guess this too is haiku worthy. My best friends are snores. / But who has come to my door? / The master of chores. Ugh, I guess I'll help. Now where did I put that rod? Oh, yes. There.

visit.speaker: Azama
visit.line: Hmm... Oh, dear, I've never seen a filthier apparatus. What HAVE you been stirring with this, Daughter? It'll have to do. Ready to help?

visit.speaker: Mitama
visit.line: OK, I guess. Just a moment... Beseeches he me? / I am the Maiden of Zs. / At the least say please.

end.speaker: Azama
end.line: Whoa, just look at that. What initiative! Tending to the wounded without even being nagged? Remarkable!

end.speaker: Mitama
end.line: Yes, it was, wasn't it? Now, good night.

end.speaker: Azama
end.line: Oh? Where do you think you're going?

end.speaker: Mitama
end.line: Very funny, Father. Inside to bed, of course. Since all of those obnoxious visitors are gone, I can get back to sleep.

end.speaker: Azama
end.line: Is it funny, how you think you're just going to hit the hay after being so useful! No, dear Daughter. You're going to accompany us.

end.speaker: Azama
end.line: All right. Let's go. No complaining. As they say; those that idle away their lives are looking for trouble.

end.speaker: Mitama
end.line: Trouble rarely travels alone. You see, Father? Anyone can spout that stuff and sound smart. I'm not buying it. I'll surely get into far more misadventures with you. Oh, well... What use is trying? / Fathers are always prying. / Daughters, complying. | Far better to sleep. / Far off in the starry night. / Far from Azama. | Good night to freedom. / Good night to aspirations. / Good night to my dreams. Huh. What do you know? Three haiku? All at once?! Travelling with Father might actually be inspiring.
